elements.content: Deprotonation of 1,3-dimethyl-2-methyleneimidazole (MeNHO) by nBuLi in hexane/benzene is fast and clean and gave a precipitate of the product in which the MeNHO ligand is cleanly lithiated in the alkene backbone (1). Lithiation of the much bulkier 1,3-bis­(2,6-di-iso-propylphenyl)-2-methyleneimidazole (DIPPNHO) needs the presence of TMEDA as a cosolvent to give backbone lithiation (2). Depending on the cosolvent, the following products could be crystallized and fully characterized by X-ray diffraction and NMR: 1-THF, 1-TMEDA, 1-(TMEDA) 0.5 , and 2-TMEDA. The MeNHO ligand with a saturated backbone is less easily lithiated by nBuLi and does not even react at elevated temperatures. Addition of TMEDA, however, already gave decomposition at room temperature by ring opening to give a complex aggregate consisting of a dilithiated ligand fragment and two lithiated TMEDA ligands. DFT calculations shed light on a possible mechanism for cleavage of one of the cyclic C–N bonds. This process, which most likely goes through prior lithiation of the saturated backbone, seems to be general for NHO ligands with saturated backbones. Convenient access to NHO ligands that have been deprotonated in the unsaturated backbone may promote this new ligand class for further exploration.

elements.content: As early as 1968, Öfele and Wanzlick independently described the first metal complexes featuring N-heterocyclic carbenes (NHCs) as ligands. These classical examples of metal-carbene complexes were prepared by an in situ generation of the carbene ligand. The discovery of stable (bottle-able) free carbenes by Bertrand and Arduengo simplified the syntheses of metal-carbene complexes enormously. Since then, these neutral carbene donors have received increasing attention as ligands in coordination chemistry and catalysis. New modifications of NHCs have been discovered, such as the abnormal NHC (aNHC) or cyclic alkylamino carbene (CAAC) (). A few years later, the neutral carbene family was extended with much stronger donating anionic ligands like the N-heterocyclic borane (NHB), which is isolobal to NHC, and the N-heterocyclic dicarbene (NHDC). The NHDC ligand has both normal and abnormal carbene centers in the imidazole ring. It undergoes coordination to Lewis acids at the abnormal carbon, and reaction with electrophiles, e.g., Me3SiCl, provides a variety of backbone-functionalized NHCs.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

As early as 1968, Öfele and Wanzlick independently described the first metal complexes featuring N-heterocyclic carbenes (NHCs) as ligands. These classical examples of metal-carbene complexes were prepared by an in situ generation of the carbene ligand. The discovery of stable (bottle-able) free carbenes by Bertrand and Arduengo simplified the syntheses of metal-carbene complexes enormously. Since then, these neutral carbene donors have received increasing attention as ligands in coordination chemistry and catalysis. New modifications of NHCs have been discovered, such as the abnormal NHC (aNHC) or cyclic alkylamino carbene (CAAC) (). A few years later, the neutral carbene family was extended with much stronger donating anionic ligands like the N-heterocyclic borane (NHB), which is isolobal to NHC, and the N-heterocyclic dicarbene (NHDC). The NHDC ligand has both normal and abnormal carbene centers in the imidazole ring. It undergoes coordination to Lewis acids at the abnormal carbon, and reaction with electrophiles, e.g., Me3SiCl, provides a variety of backbone-functionalized NHCs.

elements.clean_text: 1  NHC-Type Ligands

elements.content: Combining the NHC ligand with the the simplest carbene, CH2, gives a new class of strongly donating, neutral, carbene-like ligands that show resonance structures reminiscent of the ylene-ylid structures defined for Wittig reagents (). Although known since the early 90s, these ligands, which have been named N-heterocyclic olefins (NHOs), have recently gained increasing attention. NHO ligands provide an electron-rich and polarized exocyclic double bond due to the donating ability of the two N atoms and the delocalization of the partial positive charge over the ring. With a localized electron density on the exocyclic α-carbon of −0.69, NHOs are among the most ylidic alkenes. Because of their high p-orbital character at the exocyclic carbon, NHOs are anticipated to be softer donors than the sp2-donating NHC ligands. Tolman electronic parameters (TEPs), however, indicate NHOs to be stronger donors than NHCs.

elements.content: In a recent publication by our group, 1,3-dimethyl-2-methyleneimidazole (MeNHO) was deprotonated at the alkene backbone by an amidinate-stabilized calcium hydride complex (), giving the first example of an anionic NHO ligand (an NHO ligand with a Me3Si substituent at the exocyclic C, NHCC­(H)­SiMe3, was very recently introduced as a NHCC­(H)− synthon, but the carbanion has never been isolated). This anionic NHO ligand shows, similar to NHDC ligands, bifunctional coordination behavior. It was shown by DFT calculations that deprotonation of an NHO ligand in the backbone results in strongly increased ylidic character and electron-donating properties. Herein, we extend our preliminary investigations on the serendipitous synthesis of anionic NHO ligands and now present a facile route to anionic NHO ligands in the form of their Li complexes. Synthetic access to simple lithiated NHO reagents will be the key to further use and development of this ligand class.

elements.clean_text: 3  Formation of an Anionic NHO Ligand (C6H6, 60 °C)

elements.content: Herein, we focus on the deprotonation of a variety of NHO ligands with nBuLi in the presence of various Lewis bases. According to our previous studies, the deprotonation of 1,3-dimethyl-2-methyleneimidazole (MeNHO) by a Ca hydride reagent requires higher reaction temperatures (60 °C, ). This is mainly due to the poor solubility of the Ca reagent at room temperature. The reaction of MeNHO with the highly soluble nBuLi in C6H6 proceeded smoothly at room temperature, giving compound 1 in a high yield of 92% (). It is remarkable that this deprotonation of a weakly Brønsted-acidic sp2-CH unit does not need activation of nBuLi by a polar cosolvent. This may be explained by the strong Lewis basicity of the NHO species itself. It may act as a strongly polar ligand that, like THF or TMEDA, breaks down hexameric nBuLi aggregates into smaller, more reactive aggregates that are able to deprotonate the alkene backbone.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Herein, we focus on the deprotonation of a variety of NHO ligands with nBuLi in the presence of various Lewis bases. According to our previous studies, the deprotonation of 1,3-dimethyl-2-methyleneimidazole (MeNHO) by a Ca hydride reagent requires higher reaction temperatures (60 °C, ). This is mainly due to the poor solubility of the Ca reagent at room temperature. The reaction of MeNHO with the highly soluble nBuLi in C6H6 proceeded smoothly at room temperature, giving compound 1 in a high yield of 92% (). It is remarkable that this deprotonation of a weakly Brønsted-acidic sp2-CH unit does not need activation of nBuLi by a polar cosolvent. This may be explained by the strong Lewis basicity of the NHO species itself. It may act as a strongly polar ligand that, like THF or TMEDA, breaks down hexameric nBuLi aggregates into smaller, more reactive aggregates that are able to deprotonate the alkene backbone.

elements.clean_text: 4  Synthesis of 1, 1-THF, and 1-TMEDA

elements.content: Compound 1 is completely insoluble in aromatic and aliphatic solvents, presumably due to formation of a coordination polymer. However, it dissolves well in THF, which is able to break down the polymeric chain into discrete aggregates. However, slow diffusion of pentane into a saturated THF solution at −20 °C gave yellow crystals of the THF-solvated coordination polymer 1-THF (, ). The molecular structure of 1-THF may be viewed as a linear array of dimers. Two Li+ ions symmetrically bridge two vinylic C atoms with C–Li distances of 2.244(2)–2.255(2) Å. These dimeric subunits are connected to each other by mutual CH2···Li contacts that are slightly longer (2.312(2) Å). Additionally, each Li center binds to one THF molecule resulting in a tetrahedral coordination geometry. The (vinylic) C–Li distances are longer than those reported for NHDCs with a Li+ countercation, which range from 2.116 to 2.217 Å. The CCH2 bond length in 1-THF (1.390(2) Å) is longer than that in 1,2,3,5-tetramethyl-2-methylene-imidazole (1.357(3) Å) but significantly shorter than that in the previously reported Ca complex (1.430(6) Å). It much more resembles the value we calculated for a free, noncoordinating NHO-H anion (CCH2, 1.384 Å). This may be explained by metal-induced polarization of the CCH2 bond. Bonding of the NHO methylene group to Ca2+ instead of Li+ results in stronger polarization and therefore elongation of the Cδ+-CH2 δ¯ bond. Apparently, the somewhat larger size of Ca2+ (1.00 Å) versus Li+ (0.76 Å) is easily compensated by the higher positive charge on Ca2+. In both structures, the H atoms on the exocyclic CH2 group have been freely refined. The sum of the valence angles at the exocyclic C measure 338(3)° in the Ca complex (shown in ) and 350.3(3)° in 1-THF. This shows a much higher degree of sp3-hybridization in the Ca than in the Li complex, which is close to being sp2-hybridized. This is in agreement with the stronger polarization, and consequently more pronounced ylidic character, of the Cδ+-CH2 δ¯ bond in the Ca complex.

The THF ligand in 1-THF is only weakly bound; storing yellow crystals at room temperature under nitrogen gave a conversion into a THF-free amorphous white powder of 1. The 1H NMR spectrum of 1 in THF-d 8 is extremely simple, showing four singlets: two for the two different Me groups, one for the CH (backbone), and one for the CH2 group. Deprotonation of MeNHO led to highfield shifts for the backbone CH resonance (5.91 → 5.35 ppm) and the CH2 resonance (2.24 → 1.85 ppm).

elements.content: Deprotonation of MeNHO with nBuLi·TMEDA (benzene, 20 °C, TMEDA = N,N,N′,N′-tetramethylethylenediamine) gave, after crystallization from hexane, 1-TMEDA in 84% yield (). X-ray diffraction analysis revealed the formation of a discrete centrosymmetric dimeric Li complex consisting of two deprotonated MeNHO ligands and two Li+ cations chelated by two TMEDA ligands (a, ). Bonding of the anion to Li+ occurs exclusively via the vinylic backbone C. Apparently, the chelating TMEDA fragment is a stronger ligand than NHO itself. It is able to break the coordination polymer of 1 at its weakest spot, the Li···CH2 linkage. The structure of 1-TMEDA is therefore very similar to that of the dimer (PhLi·TMEDA)2. The anionic MeNHO ligands bridge the two Li cations asymmetrically with a shorter contact of 2.184(2) Å directed along the C’s sp2 lone-pair and a longer contact of 2.339(2) Å along its p lone-pair. A similar, but less pronounced, asymmetry is found for bridging of the Ph groups in (PhLi·TMEDA)2 (2.200/2.266 Å) or in PhLi dimers with chiral bidentate amine ligands (2.204/2.252 Å). The average value for the C–Li bonds in 1-TMEDA (2.262 Å), however, compares well with those in the dimeric PhLi structures of 2.233 and 2.228 Å, respectively. Related to 1-THF, the exocyclic double bond in 1-TMEDA (1.378(2) Å) is elongated in comparison to free NHO (calculated value, 1.359 Å; 1,3,4,5-tetramethyl-2-methylene-imidazole, 1.357(3) Å) but is shorter than in 1-THF (1.3898(17) Å) due to lack of coordination.

elements.content: On one occasion, we have isolated crystals of a complex with a different 1/TMEDA ratio from the mother liquor. Complex 1-TMEDA 0.5 crystallized as a centrosymmetric tetranuclear species and consists of four lithiated NHO ligands and two TMEDA ligands (b, ). The aggregate can be described as a cut-out of the coordination polymer 1-THF. Replacing THF for the cosolvent TMEDA inhibits the formation of a coordination polymer and gives a discrete aggregate.

Complex 1-TMEDA  0.5  crystallized as a centrosymmetric tetranuclear species and consists of four lithiated NHO ligands and two TMEDA ligands (b, ). The aggregate can be described as a cut-out of the coordination polymer 1-THF. Replacing THF for the cosolvent TMEDA inhibits the formation of a coordination polymer and gives a discrete aggregate.

elements.content: For investigating the influence of steric bulk of the substituents at N, the methyl groups in MeNHO were exchanged for bulky 2,6-di-iso-propylphenyl (DIPP) groups. 1,3-Bis­(2,6-di-iso-propylphenyl)-2-methyleneimidazole (DIPPNHO) does not undergo a reaction with nBuLi in C6H6, even not after heating to reflux temperature. This could be due to limited accessibility of the backbone CH unit on account of the large DIPP substituent. It may, however, also be due to the limited Lewis basicity of this bulkier NHO ligand, which is therefore less able to break down the hexameric nBuLi aggregate into smaller, more reactive units. The latter was found to be the case: by addition of TMEDA, DIPPNHO was deprotonated already at room temperature to give 2-TMEDA ().

elements.content: Compound 2-TMEDA crystallizes as a monomer with one deprotonated DIPPNHO ligand and one TMEDA ligand bound to Li, resulting in a trigonal planar coordination geometry (, ). The C–Li bond length (2.028(3) Å) is significantly shorter than those in the structures of 1-THF or 1-TMEDA in which the anionic NHO ligands are bridging and Li is tetracoordinate. The C–CH2 bond length (C1–C2 1.365(2) Å) falls in the range expected for a noncoordinating fragment and indicates weak polarization of the Cδ+-CH2 δ¯ bond and thus high ylene character. The high ylene character is confirmed by the location of the CCH2 protons in the crystal structure. This unit is essentially planar: the sum of the valence angles at the terminal C is 359.7(34)°. In contrast to 1-THF, the chemical shift of the residual proton in the backbone is shifted downfield from 5.77 ppm in the 1H NMR spectrum in C6D6 to 5.94 ppm. Because of backbone deprotonation, the symmetry of the NHO breaks down, resulting in a double signal set for the DIPP substituents. The high ylene character of the CCH2 fragment is confirmed by the presence of two broad signals for the CH2 protons (2.23 and 2.29 ppm), implying hindered rotation around the CC bond. Heating the sample to 48 °C led to coalescence to give a singlet (ΔG ‡ = 16.2 kcal/mol, Figure S4).

elements.content: DFT calculations at the B3PW91/6-311++G** level reproduced the structure of 2-TMEDA very well (see Supporting Information for details). Calculations of the NPA charges showed that the CCH2 bond has increased ylide character (charge at CH2 = −0.79; compare to charge at CH2 in neutral MeNHO = −0.69). This underscores the clear increase in electron-donating properties upon lithiation of the backbone.

elements.content: For investigating the influence of a saturated backbone, 1,3-dimethyl-2-methyleneimidazolidine was reacted with nBuLi in benzene, and up to 80 °C, no reaction could be observed. Conversion of the NHO ligand could only be reached after addition of TMEDA (20 °C), resulting in the precipitation of a white solid that could be recrystallized from aromatic solvents. The crystal structure (, ) shows that the NHO ring opened, giving a dianionic fragment. The dilithiated fragment crystallizes with two equivalents of lithiated TMEDA (which is known to be easily deprotonated in the Me group) to give the tetranuclear complex 3 that crystallizes with half an equivalent of NHO, which is not coordinated and simply behaves as a cocrystallized solvent ().

elements.content:
Energies between squared brackets relate to calculations on a model including chelation of Li with TMEDA (Figure S7).

Although complex 3 does not contain crystallographic symmetry, an approximate mirror plane runs through the ring-opened NHO fragment, Li3 and Li4. The lithium atoms Li1, Li2, and Li4 display a distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry with a coordination number of four, whereas Li3 is surrounded exclusively by three carbanions (C5, C12, and C18), inducing a trigonal geometry. The C–Li bond distances for the 4-fold coordinated Li1, Li2, and Li4 (Li1–C5 2.252(3) Å, Li2–C5 2.231(3) Å, Li4–C12 2.289(3) Å, Li4–C18 2.243(3) Å) are somewhat longer than those for three coordinate Li3 (Li3–C5 2.118(3) Å, Li3–C12 2.186(3) Å, Li3–C18 2.157 (3) Å). These C–Li distances all compare well with those reported for Li-CH2N­(Me)­CH2CH2NMe2 complexes, which range from 2.101 to 2.347 Å. The Li–N bond lengths can be divided into three groups. Bond distances to the negatively charged nitrogen N2 are the shortest (Li1–N2 1.958(3) Å, Li2–N2 1.998(3) Å). This is followed by the somewhat longer bond distances to the N atoms of deprotonated TMEDA (Li1–N5 2.066(3) Å; Li1–N6 2.061(3) Å; Li2–N3 2.085(3) Å; Li2–N4 2.061(3) Å). The weakest and longest interaction can be observed between Li4 and the neutral TMEDA ligand (Li4–N7 2.158(3) Å; Li4–N8 2.131(3) Å). Diffusion-ordered NMR spectroscopy (DOSY) shows that complex 3 likely retains its tetranuclear structure in C6D6 solution: estimated molecular weight of 453 g/mol (calcd 484.52 g/mol) (D = 6.680 × 10–10 m2/s, r = 5.401 Å, V = 660 Å3; see Supporting Information). This is confirmed by 7Li NMR spectroscopy, which gives three resonances in the ratio 2:1:1 at 1.16 ppm (Li1, Li2), (Li1, Li2), 2.44 ppm and 2.86 ppm (the latter two are assigned to Li3 and Li4).

elements.content: The many examples of ring opening and expansion of NHC ligands has been previously reviewed. There are only a few examples of s-block metal-mediated NHC decomposition, and the mechanisms are generally speculative. As the herein described ring opening of an NHO ligand by nBuLi is the first of its kind, we investigated its details by DFT methods at the B3PW91/6-311++G** level (see Supporting Information for details). We have calculated the initial metalation step followed by ring opening (b). Starting with the Li intermediate, the ring opening process can be best described as a ß-amide elimination. This leads to elongation and finally cleavage of one of the C–N bonds, giving a unique Li-amide complex in which a pendant vinyl moiety coordinates to Li. The calculated activation energy for this process is relatively high (ΔG = +25.4 kcal/mol) but including TMEDA as a chelating ligand for Li led to a substantial lowering (ΔG = +21.3 kcal/mol, see Figure S7), whereas the geometries of minima and transition states only slightly changed. The calculated transition state shows that a simple 1,3-shift of Li can lead to C–N bond cleavage. The activation energy for ring opening of an NHO ligand with DIPP substituents at both N atoms was found to be slightly lower than that for the ligand with N-Me substituents (see Supporting Information), implying that such decomposition reactions can also be expected for bulkier NHO ligands.

This leads to elongation and finally cleavage of one of the C-N bonds, giving a unique Li-amide complex in which a pendant vinyl moiety coordinates to Li. The calculated activation energy for this process is relatively high (ΔG = +25.4 kcal/mol) but including TMEDA as a chelating ligand for Li led to a substantial lowering (ΔG = +21.3 kcal/mol, see Figure S7), whereas the geometries of minima and transition states only slightly changed. The calculated transition state shows that a simple 1,3-shift of Li can lead to C-N bond cleavage. elements.content: The MeNHO ligand can be very easily deprotonated by nBuLi in an aromatic solvent at room temperature. The lithiation in the alkene backbone of the ligand is fast and clean and surprisingly needs no activation by polar solvents or cosolvents. It is likely that the NHO ligand itself breaks down the larger nBuLi clusters into smaller, more reactive aggregates. The bulkier NHO ligand DIPPNHO, however, could not be lithiated even at elevated temperatures. Addition of the chelating solvent TMEDA gave a smooth lithiation in the alkene backbone.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The MeNHO ligand can be very easily deprotonated by nBuLi in an aromatic solvent at room temperature. The lithiation in the alkene backbone of the ligand is fast and clean and surprisingly needs no activation by polar solvents or cosolvents. It is likely that the NHO ligand itself breaks down the larger nBuLi clusters into smaller, more reactive aggregates. The bulkier NHO ligand DIPPNHO, however, could not be lithiated even at elevated temperatures. Addition of the chelating solvent TMEDA gave a smooth lithiation in the alkene backbone.

elements.content: Crystal structures of several lithiated NHO ligands show a strong dependence on the cosolvent. Addition of THF led to linear coordination polymers in which coordinated THF ligands prevent further aggregation to 3D networks. Addition of the chelating ligand TMEDA led to discrete di- or tetranuclear aggregates or, in the case of DIPPNHO, to a monomeric lithiated NHO complex.

elements.content: The MeNHO ligand with an unsaturated backbone does not react with nBuLi, but addition of TMEDA led to a ring-opening reaction to give a complex aggregate consisting of a dilithiated ligand fragment and two lithiated TMEDA ligands. DFT calculations shed light on a possible mechanism for cleavage of one of the cyclic C–N bonds. This process, which most likely goes through prior lithiation of the saturated backbone, seems to be general for NHO ligands with saturated backbones.

elements.content:
Convenient access to NHO ligands that have been deprotonated in the unsaturated backbone may promote this new ligand class for further exploration.

Experimental SectionGeneral Considerations

All experiments were carried out under an atmosphere of N2 using standard Schlenk techniques and freshly dried and degassed solvents (all solvents were dried over a column except for THF, which was dried over Na and redistilled). The following compounds were synthesized according to literature procedures: 1,3-dimethyl-2-methyleneimidazole, 1,3-bis­(2,6-diisopropylphenyl)-2-methyleneimidazole, and 1,3-dimethyl-2-methyleneimidazolidine. NMR spectra were measured on Bruker Avance III HD 400 MHz or Bruker Avance III HD 600 MHz spectrometers. Crystal structures have been measured on a SuperNova (Agilent) diffractometer with dual Cu and Mo microfocus sources and an Atlas S2 detector. Crystallographic data have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre as supplementary publication no. 1860446 (1-THF), 1860447 (1-TMEDA), 1860448 (1-TMEDA 0.5 ), 1860449 (2-TMEDA) and 1860450 (3). Copies of the data can be obtained free of charge on application to CCDC, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB21EZ, UK (fax: (+44)­1223-336-033; e-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk).

elements.content: 1,3-Dimethyl-2-methyleneimidazole (MeNHO, 0.103 g, 0.935 mmol) was dissolved in benzene (2 mL), and nBuLi (0.374 mL, 0.935 mmol, 2.5 M) was added dropwise at room temperature. After 5 min, a white solid precipitated. The reaction mixture was stirred for a further 3 h. The residue obtained after centrifugation and decantation of the mother liquor was washed with hexane (2 × 2 mL) and dried under high vacuum to give complex 1 as a highly air sensitive white powder (0.100 g, 0.861 mmol, 92%). 1H NMR (400.13 MHz, THF-d 8, 298 K): δ 1.85 (2H, s, CH2), 2.77 (3H, s, CH3), 2.98 (3H, s, CH3), 5.35 (1H, s, CH). 13C­{1H} NMR (100.62 MHz, THF-d 8, 298 K): δ 32.63 (CH2), 32.73 (CH3), 37.13 (CH3), 120.72 (CH), 156.46 (C-vinyl), 156.97 (C-vinyl). 7Li NMR: (223.23 MHz, C6D6, 298 K, external referencing: LiCl in H2O): 1.14 ppm. Single crystals of 1-THF suitable for X-ray diffraction measurements could be obtained by slow diffusion of pentane into a saturated THF solution of 1 at −20 °C. Elemental analyses of 1 or 1-THF were not successful due to the very high air sensitivity and partial loss of coordinated solvent molecules.

After 5 min, a white solid precipitated. The reaction mixture was stirred for a further 3 h. The residue obtained after centrifugation and decantation of the mother liquor was washed with hexane (2 × 2 mL) and dried under high vacuum to give complex 1 as a highly air sensitive white powder (0.100 g, 0.861 mmol, 92%). 1H NMR (400.13 MHz, THF-d 8, 298 K): δ 1.85 (2H, s, CH2), 2.77 (3H, s, CH3), 2.98 (3H, s, CH3), 5.35 (1H, s, CH). 13C{1H} NMR (100.62 MHz, THF-d 8, 298 K): δ 32.63 (CH2), 32.73 (CH3), 37.13 (CH3), 120.72 (CH), 156.46 (C-vinyl), 156.97 (C-vinyl). 7Li NMR: (223.23 MHz, C6D6, 298 K, external referencing: LiCl in H2O): 1.14 ppm. elements.content: nBuLi (0.381 mL, 0.953 mmol, 2.5 M) was added dropwise to a solution of 1,3-dimethyl-2-methyleneimidazole (MeNHO, 0.105 g, 0.953 mmol) and TMEDA (0.443 g, 3.81 mmol, 0.572 mL) in C6H6 (2 mL) at room temperature. The solution turned yellow and was stirred overnight at room temperature. After removal of the solvent, the crude product was washed with hexane (2 × 2 mL) and dried under vacuum to give the title compound as a highly air sensitive white powder (0.185 g, 0.796 mmol, 84%). 1H NMR (400.13 MHz, C6D6, 298 K): δ 1.85 (4H, s, CH2-TMEDA), 1.94 (12H, s, CH3-TMEDA), 2.57 (2H, s, CH2), 2.94 (3H, s, CH3), 3.20 (3H, s, CH3), 5.58 (1H, s, CH). 13C­{1H} NMR (100.62 MHz, C6D6, 298 K): δ 32.73 (CH3), 33.61 (CH2), 37.78 (CH3), 46.43 (CH3-TMEDA), 57.49 (CH2-TMEDA), 121.14 (CH), 156.17 (C-vinyl), 156.66 (C-vinyl). 7Li NMR: (223.23 MHz, C6D6, 298 K, external referencing: LiCl in H2O): 1.73 ppm. Elemental analyses of 1-TMEDA was not successful due to its very high air sensitivity.

1,3-Dimethyl-2-methyleneimidazole (MeNHO, 0.103 g, 0.935 mmol) was dissolved in benzene (2 mL), and nBuLi (0.374 mL, 0.935 mmol, 2.5 M) was added dropwise at room temperature. After 5 min, a white solid precipitated. The reaction mixture was stirred for a further 3 h. The residue obtained after centrifugation and decantation of the mother liquor was washed with hexane (2 × 2 mL) and dried under high vacuum to give complex 1 as a highly air sensitive white powder (0.100 g, 0.861 mmol, 92%). 1H NMR (400.13 MHz, THF-d 8, 298 K): δ 1.85 (2H, s, CH2), 2.77 (3H, s, CH3), 2.98 (3H, s, CH3), 5.35 (1H, s, CH). 13C­{1H} NMR (100.62 MHz, THF-d 8, 298 K): δ 32.63 (CH2), 32.73 (CH3), 37.13 (CH3), 120.72 (CH), 156.46 (C-vinyl), 156.97 (C-vinyl). 7Li NMR: (223.23 MHz, C6D6, 298 K, external referencing: LiCl in H2O): 1.14 ppm. Single crystals of 1-THF suitable for X-ray diffraction measurements could be obtained by slow diffusion of pentane into a saturated THF solution of 1 at −20 °C. Elemental analyses of 1 or 1-THF were not successful due to the very high air sensitivity and partial loss of coordinated solvent molecules.

Synthesis of <bold>1-TMEDA</bold>

nBuLi (0.381 mL, 0.953 mmol, 2.5 M) was added dropwise to a solution of 1,3-dimethyl-2-methyleneimidazole (MeNHO, 0.105 g, 0.953 mmol) and TMEDA (0.443 g, 3.81 mmol, 0.572 mL) in C6H6 (2 mL) at room temperature. The solution turned yellow and was stirred overnight at room temperature. After removal of the solvent, the crude product was washed with hexane (2 × 2 mL) and dried under vacuum to give the title compound as a highly air sensitive white powder (0.185 g, 0.796 mmol, 84%). 1H NMR (400.13 MHz, C6D6, 298 K): δ 1.85 (4H, s, CH2-TMEDA), 1.94 (12H, s, CH3-TMEDA), 2.57 (2H, s, CH2), 2.94 (3H, s, CH3), 3.20 (3H, s, CH3), 5.58 (1H, s, CH). 13C­{1H} NMR (100.62 MHz, C6D6, 298 K): δ 32.73 (CH3), 33.61 (CH2), 37.78 (CH3), 46.43 (CH3-TMEDA), 57.49 (CH2-TMEDA), 121.14 (CH), 156.17 (C-vinyl), 156.66 (C-vinyl). 7Li NMR: (223.23 MHz, C6D6, 298 K, external referencing: LiCl in H2O): 1.73 ppm. Single crystals of 1-TMEDA suitable for X-ray diffraction measurements could be obtained by slowly diffusing pentane vapor into a saturated toluene solution at −20 °C. Elemental analyses of 1-TMEDA was not successful due to its very high air sensitivity.

Synthesis of <bold>2-TMEDA</bold>

1,3-Bis­(2,6-di-iso-propylphenyl)-2-methyleneimidazole (DIPPNHO, 0.212 g, 0.526 mmol) and TMEDA (0.061 g, 0.526 mmol, 79.0 μL) were dissolved in benzene (2 mL), and nBuLi (0.211 mL, 0.526 mmol, 2.5 M) was added dropwise at room temperature. The solution turned yellow and was stirred overnight at room temperature. After removal of the solvent, the yellow solid was dissolved in hexane (1.5 mL) and stored at −20 °C. Yellow crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction grew overnight, which were washed with cold hexane (1 mL) and dried under a vacuum to yield 0.183 g of crystals. Further crystals (0.020 g) were obtained by storing the mother liquor at −20 °C. Overall yield: 0.203 g, 0.387 mmol, 74%. 1H NMR (600.13, C6D6, 298 K): δ 1.37 (6H, d, J = 7.0 Hz, CH3-iPr), 1.40 (4H, s, CH2-TMEDA), 1.44 (6H, d, J = 6.9 Hz, CH3-iPr), 1.52 (s, 12H, CH3-TMEDA), 1.56 (6H, d, J = 6.9 Hz, CH3-iPr), 1.60 (6H, d, J = 6.9 Hz, CH3-iPr), 2.41 (2H, bs, CH2), 3.78 (2H, h, J = 6.9 Hz, CH-iPr), 3.88 (2H, hept, J = 7.0 Hz, CH-iPr), 5.94 (1H, s, CH), 7.24–7.28 (3H, m, CH-arom), 7.33 (3H, s, CH-arom). 13C NMR (150.92 MHz, C6D6, 298 K): δ 24.31 (CH3- iPr), 24.48­(CH3- iPr), 24.50 (CH3- iPr), 24.64 (CH3-iPr), 28.37­(CH- iPr), 28.62 (CH- iPr), 38.66 (CH2). 44.40 (CH3-TMEDA), 55.74 (CH2-TMEDA), 120.53 (CH), 123.70 (CH-arom), 124.17 (CH-arom), 126.67 (CH-arom), 127.78 (CH-arom), 128.35 (C-vinyl), 138.50 (C-arom), 143.65 (C-arom), 149.02 (C-arom), 149.60 (C-arom), 154.78 (C-Li). 7Li NMR (223.23 MHz, C6D6, 298 K, external referencing: LiCl in H2O): 1.87 ppm. Elemental analysis: Calcd for C34H53LiN4 (M = 524.77 g/mol): C 77.82, H 10.18, N 10.68; Found: C 77.40, H 9.68, N 10.07. Although these results are outside the range viewed as establishing analytical purity, they are provided to illustrate the best values obtained to date.
